qas.question: Which states have not adopted FRCP?

answers.text: New York, Illinois, and California are the most significant

qas.question: How do New York, Illinois and California maintain civil procedure laws?

answers.text: codified statutes enacted by the state legislature

qas.question: What should New York, Illinois and California be using instead of codified statutes?

answers.text: court rules promulgated by the state supreme court

qas.question: Which three states adopted the FRCP?
How many states no longer have civil procedure laws from state legislature?
What did California claim was wrong with state legislature?

plausible_answers.text: court rules promulgated by the state supreme court

qas.question: California refuses to use codified statutes instead of what?
Key portions of what were changed to make the legislature more distinct?

context: <a0_0><b3_0>New York, Illinois, and California<b3_0/> are the most significant<a0_0/> states that have not adopted the FRCP. Furthermore, all <b4_0>three<b4_0/> states continue to maintain most of their civil procedure laws in the form of <a1_0>codified statutes enacted by the state legislature<a1_0/>, as opposed to <a2_0><b6_0>court rules promulgated by the state supreme court<b6_0/><a2_0/>, on the ground that the latter are <b5_0>undemocratic<b5_0/>. But certain key portions of their <b7_0>civil procedure laws<b7_0/> have been modified by their legislatures to bring them closer to federal civil procedure.
